unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Spin the Spinner Probability
question_text:
A spinner consists of $8$ equally sized sections. Each section is labeled with a different number from $1$ to $8$.
If the spinner is spun five times and the result on each spin is independent, what is the probability that the number $3$ will come up on exactly two of the spins?
solution:
This problem involves the calculation of a probability related to the binomial setting. When calculating a binomial probability, remember to account for all observations ($5$ in this case) and remember to account for all of the different orders in which success can be achieved (the number $3$ can come up on any two of the five spins).

Consider landing on the number 3 to be a success. Let X represent the number of times the spinner will land on the number 3 when the spinner is spun 5 times. We are looking for p(X=2).

The binompdf function finds the probability of obtaining exactly x successes
in n observations
. The syntax is:

binompdf(n,p,X)

n
is the number of observations,
p
is the probability of success, and
x
is the number of observations that result in success.
